citations.desc: Procurement of dogs, cats, and other animals; dealers.
citations.narrative:
On November 24, 2024, the facility purchased one male ring-tailed lemur from an individual who is not licensed with the
USDA.
Purchasing animals from sellers who are required to have a license but do not prevents APHIS from ensuring the well-
being of those animals at their originating facility. No dealer or exhibitor shall knowingly obtain any dog, cat, or other
animal from any person who is required to be licensed but who does not hold a current, valid, and unsuspended license.

The enclosure housing two capybara does not have a sufficient perimeter fence. The capybara enclosure utilizes the
facility's perimeter fence for two of the four walls, leaving it without a separate, secondary fence that is at least three feet
away.
An insufficient perimeter fence cannot effectively act as secondary containment for the animals inside and can allow
unwanted animals or people to enter the facility and potentially harm the animals within. Primary enclosures that are less
than three feet away from the perimeter fence may allow unwanted contact between animals inside the enclosure and
people or animals outside the perimeter fence which could lead to injury or disease spread. The perimeter fence must be
constructed so that it protects the animals in the facility by restricting animals and unauthorized persons from going
through it or under it and having contact with the animals in the facility, and so that it can function as a secondary
containment system for the animals in the facility. It must be of sufficient height (at least six feet high) to keep animals and
unauthorized persons out. It must be of sufficient distance (at least three feet) from the outside of the primary enclosure to
prevent physical contact between animals inside the enclosure and animals or persons outside the perimeter fence.
This inspection was a site approval inspection.
This site is not ready for approval to conduct activity covered under your current Animal Welfare Act License.
Conducting regulated activities at a non-approved site is a violation of the Animal Welfare Act.
Please contact your inspector to schedule your next new site approval inspection.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
